Bug.Summery: Remove old translated property files from SSE
Bug.WithStack:
There are some old translated property files in SSE. They do not contain all the messages that we currently used in WTP 0.7. Although these property files are not being used at all, they are confusing and I think we should clean them up for 0.7. Given that we're just removing old translated property files and not changing any code, I believe this is a very low risk fix.
Arthur, can you approve this fix for RC2? The translations for the following files are currently in our builds: org.eclipse.jst.jsp.ui\templates\jspdefault-templates.properties org.eclipse.wst.css.ui\templates\cssdefault-templates.properties org.eclipse.wst.html.core\data\htmref.properties org.eclipse.wst.html.ui\templates\htmldefault-templates.properties org.eclipse.wst.sse.core\config\charset.properties org.eclipse.wst.xml.ui\templates\xmldefault-templates.properties
The translations (and only the translations) can be deleted now that they are repackaged in NL fragments. Created attachment 24872 org.eclipse.jst.jsp.ui.patch Created attachment 24873 org.eclipse.wst.html.core.patch Created attachment 24874 org.eclipse.wst.html.ui.patch Created attachment 24875 org.eclipse.wst.sse.core.patch Created attachment 24876 org.eclipse.wst.sse.core.patch Created attachment 24877 org.eclipse.wst.xml.ui.patch David, I've attached the patches to fix this bug. If it gets approved for RC2, please release. Thanks. Approved subject to agreement from David that this will have no impact. Yes, no impact, just property files. Amy, you attached sse.core patch twice ... what that just a browser click error? Or ... is there yet another patch you intended to include?
accident. sorry. I went ahead and just made one obsolete. just re-assigning to Amy since she did the work ... thanks for slogging through with all the NL teams to get them to package fragments in a friendly way.
is in 7/18 I-builds.
Verified. closing verified

Bug.Summery: [PropertiesView] icons in Properties view do not work properly

Lines.Line: - implement an IPropertySource and property descriptors which use a label
provider that gives an image to one or more properties -- the icon is in the
property display value, not in the property label.
- once there is at least one icon being displayed (in the "Value" column), the
the text in the "Property" column is indented, as though it were also
expecting (or requiring) its own image icon.
- if no properties make use of an image, then the whole thing looks fine

Bug.WithStack:
This bug was introduce around 3.1M6, as it was not reproducable in 3.1M4. It's still a problem in the release build and seems to be directly related to changing the implementation of Properties from using a table to using a tree control. This might be a problem on Windows only.
How to reproduce it: - implement an IPropertySource and property descriptors which use a label provider that gives an image to one or more properties -- the icon is in the property display value, not in the property label. - once there is at least one icon being displayed (in the "Value" column), the the text in the "Property" column is indented, as though it were also expecting (or requiring) its own image icon. - if no properties make use of an image, then the whole thing looks fine
Here's an example to give an idea of how it looks:
(with no icon) + MyCategory | MyProperty | MyValue
(with an icon [*]) + MyCategory | MyPrope...| [*] MyValue
Bug.WithOutStack:
This bug was introduce around 3.1M6, as it was not reproducable in 3.1M4. It's still a problem in the release build and seems to be directly related to changing the implementation of Properties from using a table to using a tree control. This might be a problem on Windows only.
How to reproduce it: - implement an IPropertySource and property descriptors which use a label provider that gives an image to one or more properties -- the icon is in the property display value, not in the property label. - once there is at least one icon being displayed (in the "Value" column), the the text in the "Property" column is indented, as though it were also expecting (or requiring) its own image icon. - if no properties make use of an image, then the whole thing looks fine
Here's an example to give an idea of how it looks:
(with no icon) + MyCategory | MyProperty | MyValue
(with an icon [*]) + MyCategory | MyPrope...| [*] MyValue

Bug.Summery: Additional GenModel property to differentiate Interface package
Bug.WithStack:
The existing GenModel property "basePackage" allows the user to specify the java package name used when generating the model package.
We have a requirement for api reasons, to differentiate the Interface and Implementation classes into different packages.
Please add an optional property: "interfacePackage" or something similar, that would help this type of setup. Currently regening and merging in this type of environment is a nightmare...
Thanks.... We already did this in 2.1. Select a package in the generator, and look in the properties under "Package Suffixes". You'll see all the defaults for the packages we generate, and you can change any of them.
Each package is named like this: base package + package name + package suffix
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 96041 *** Excellent thanks!!!!!
Is there a new pty file for Rose? or is this only in the Gen model? No, there's no new property file and the Rose importer doesn't handle these. You'll have to edit them right in the generator.
Bug.WithOutStack:
The existing GenModel property "basePackage" allows the user to specify the java package name used when generating the model package.
We have a requirement for api reasons, to differentiate the Interface and Implementation classes into different packages.
Please add an optional property: "interfacePackage" or something similar, that would help this type of setup. Currently regening and merging in this type of environment is a nightmare...
Thanks.... We already did this in 2.1. Select a package in the generator, and look in the properties under "Package Suffixes". You'll see all the defaults for the packages we generate, and you can change any of them.
Each package is named like this: base package + package name + package suffix
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 96041 *** Excellent thanks!!!!!
Is there a new pty file for Rose? or is this only in the Gen model? No, there's no new property file and the Rose importer doesn't handle these. You'll have to edit them right in the generator.

Bug.Summery: Make 'hasMainType' and 'isApplet' property tests part of launching plug-in
Bug.WithStack:
To consider with launch simplification:
Currently the property tests for 'isMainType' and 'isApplet' are part of the java debug UI plug-in (JavaElementPropertyTester), which means the plug-in must be loaded for the property testers to be effective. By moving to the launching plug-in the testers will be loaded sooner (as JUI pre-reqs lanuching), meaning that the available launch options will be better scoped sooner, reducing the available options in the run/debug cascade. Consider with launching work in 3.2 We should make reusable property tests that are useful for all shortcuts in the SDK such as:
* hasMethod (name/signature) * isSubclass (of fully qualified name) * references (package name, like 'org.eclipse.swt')
By putting these tests in the org.eclipse.jdt.debug plug-in or the org.eclipse.jdt.debug.launching plug-in they will be lower on the food chain and more likely be loaded for launch shortcuts to be more 'selective' in the UI. Created attachment 28195 patch (part A)
minor fixes to the context launching action Created attachment 28196 patch (part B)
adds the new class in org.eclispe.jdt.debug for generalized enablement tests to be shared by other plugins Created attachment 28197 patch (part C)
enablement changes to org.eclipse.jdt.debug.ui to use the new PropertyTests from patch B please verify Kevin. Michael, in light of the fix for bug 112455, does the new property tester just consider super classes when testing for applets, rather than supertypes? (Just want to make sure this fix does not 'wipe out' the fix to bug 112455). no, this patch adds in the new PropertyTester but leaves the other one(s) alone, just in case they are used elsewhere. Created attachment 28335 updated patch
prunes out an old test that violates plugin access restrictions,
Please verify Kevin. reviewed code and released patches. Added a couple null checks. Darin please verify. Verified.
* Added build notes to describe new property tests. * Changed "hasLibraryRef" to "hasImport" to be more descriptive (I hope :-). Fixed bug in "import" test to chech if import exists * removed the "method visibility" modifier from the hasMethod test. As well, added test for main method in binaries as "main, ([Ljava/lang/String;)V" I've re-worked the property testers:
* Moved to jdt.launching plug-in (I found that the launching plug-in is active when the jdt.debug plug-in is not, and provides better behavior) * Changed test set to: hasMain, extendsClass, extendsInterface, hasMethod, isContainer, hasProjectNature, buildpathReference * Supplied updated patches to PDE and JUnit (bug 115008 and bug 125974). The property tester was incorrectly short circuiting when a java element was a project, pkg root, or pkg. See JavaLaunchableTester in jdt.launching. Please verify, Mike. verified.

By putting these tests in the org.eclipse.jdt.debug plug-in or the org.eclipse.jdt.debug.launching plug-in they will be lower on the food chain and more likely be loaded for launch shortcuts to be more 'selective' in the UI. Created attachment 28195 patch (part A)
minor fixes to the context launching action Created attachment 28196 patch (part B)

Bug.Summery: EJB deployment on JonAS is not possible

Lines.Line: 1. jonas-ejb-jar.xml was not generated, so i went to the J2EE Annotations
preference and checked the ejbdoclet JonAS for JonAS.
2. jonas-ejb-jar.xml was generated but it is not updated with the beans
created.
3. The stubs/skeletons code is not generated so beans are not usable at all.
Naci 1 and 2 looks like a xdoclet problem. I am investigating the 3.
Hi guys,
1) Jonas needs a special xdoclet library that needs to be downloaded seperately
from ObjectWeb and copied into the xdoclet lib folder. The file can be found at:
http://forge.objectweb.org/project/showfiles.php?group_id=5
for example for Jonas 4.2 download xdocletForJOnAS42.zip
http://forge.objectweb.org/project/download.php?group_id=5&file_id=2945
2) Jonas requires EJB compiler to preprocess files prior to deployment (unlike
jboss, weblogic, websphere). I have requested an enhancement at JOnAS newgroups
for this and opened an tracker
http://forge.objectweb.org/tracker/index.php?func=detail&aid=303779&group_id=5&atid=350005
3) JOnAS cannot treat ejb-client.jar properly. Developers will need to create
very plain EJB modules. I opened a bug at JOnAS.
4) Migrated the new generic serverdef from Lomboz to WTP, that integrates JOnAS
ejbjar task into the publish process. That should provide solution to this bug.
The solution should be available with RC2.

Bug.Summery: Debug Views Update Policy (model proxy)
Bug.WithStack:
Debug views need to be more flexible in view updates and allow models to have better control on when/how views should be updated. Created attachment 24870 Design Document on View Update Policy Under consideration for 3.2 Can we shut this one down now that we have Update Policies for each of our views and we have model proxies and model proxy deltas to allow the model to control the view better? The view update policy is now static and it's default to update immediately after a model delta event. Are there plans to make that more pluggable? Or are we relying solely on model proxy to fire events differently based on some update policy setting?
We can close this one as this is a generic bug to look at update policies in general. If we need more enhancements with the current implementation of update policies, we can open new ones.
Sam We don't plan to make update policies more pluggable in 3.2. The intent is that developers will subclass and create their own update policies as requried. The default policy is to update all the time based on the model proxy. The model proxy allows a model to drive the view updating.
The only other generic update policy we could have is "udpate on demand" - i.e. Refresh (F5). I'm not sure we need that right now.
I agree to close, as we've done what we intended here. More specific bugs can be opened as required.
Marking fixed (update policy == model proxy here). Verified.

Marking fixed (update policy == model proxy here). Verified.

Bug.Summery: Comment template fails

Lines.Line: 1. Create a new workspace
2. Import above templates to ant templates
3. Create java project
4. Create build.xml file
5. Open with Ant Editor
6. <Ctrl><Space> and select "Buildfile template"
7. Select line with "</description>" (line 13 in template)
8. <Ctrl><Space> and select "Comment line -"
9. Dialog Box as attached appears.
10. Press "Ok"
11. Nothing happens to build file
Thank you for the exact steps...if only all bug reports contained steps like
these :-)

Bug.WithStack:
I added the templates as described in https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=41118#c5
When selecting a word and invoking ctrl-space and selecting the "comment word" template a small "empty" message box opens containing an "OK" button, the error icon (red circle with white cross) and a headline "Template..." only.
There are no entries in the error log. I cannot reproduce this problem on Eclipse 3.2 dev stream. (In reply to comment #1) > I cannot reproduce this problem on Eclipse 3.2 dev stream.

I'm using Eclipse 3.2M2 on Windows 2000 with JDK 5 (build 1.5.0_04-b05)
Here are my templates:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?><templates><template autoinsert="true" context="org.eclipse.ant.ui.templateContextType.task" deleted="false" description="" enabled="true" name="comment line"><!--  ${line_selection}  --></template><template autoinsert="true" context="org.eclipse.ant.ui.templateContextType.task" deleted="false" description="" enabled="true" name="comment word"><!-- ${word_selection} --> </template></templates>
Steps to reproduce: 1. Create a new workspace 2. Import above templates to ant templates 3. Create java project 4. Create build.xml file 5. Open with Ant Editor 6. <Ctrl><Space> and select "Buildfile template" 7. Select line with "</description>" (line 13 in template) 8. <Ctrl><Space> and select "Comment line -" 9. Dialog Box as attached appears. 10. Press "Ok" 11. Nothing happens to build file Thank you for the exact steps...if only all bug reports contained steps like these :-)
Able to reproduce. CC Tom for the similarities to bug 126662.
Tom can you help out by detailing what was fixed in the Java space to help me more quickly narrow down what needs to be fixed here...or if it is a general bug in the template framework for non Java template completions (In reply to comment #8) > CC Tom for the similarities to bug 126662. > > Tom can you help out by detailing what was fixed in the Java space to help me > more quickly narrow down what needs to be fixed here...or if it is a general > bug in the template framework for non Java template completions
The fix was Java(doc) only, and the fix was to use the Position based constructor of DocumentTemplateContext in order to track the active area where the template is being expanded.
The trace in comment 4 seems not related to templates however and I doubt it triggered that "error dialog".
I could reproduce the error, and I believe it is due to a bug in AntContext::getEnd. The method currently returns the length of the active area, but it should return its end offset. The following patch fixed that particular problem in my workspace (beware of line breaks):
Index: Ant Editor/org/eclipse/ant/internal/ui/editor/templates/AntContext.java =================================================================== RCS file: /cvsroot/eclipse/org.eclipse.ant.ui/Ant Editor/org/eclipse/ant/internal/ui/editor/templates/AntContext.java,v retrieving revision 1.11 diff -u -r1.11 AntContext.java --- Ant Editor/org/eclipse/ant/internal/ui/editor/templates/AntContext.java 23 Feb 2005 17:31:02 -0000 1.11 +++ Ant Editor/org/eclipse/ant/internal/ui/editor/templates/AntContext.java 8 Feb 2006 08:48:55 -0000 @@ -67,7 +67,7 @@ if (replacementOffset > 0 && getDocument().get().charAt(replacementOffset - 1) == '<') { replacementLength++; } - return replacementLength; + return replacementOffset + replacementLength; }
/* (non-Javadoc)
Thanks for the help Tom. This pointed me in the right direction.
There was the bug you found and then we also needed to consider selection when setting up the context.
Fixed in AntContext and AntEditorCompletionProcessor. I also added the comment templates as defaults so there are changes to ant.properties and ant.xml in the templates folder. Please verify Kevin. verified Closing - verified in 3.2M5 ;-)

Bug.Summery: Bugzilla refresh fails if task active

Lines.Line: - On refresh, if a report is active but not in any category (e.g. query
category or task category) then add it to the root, and pop up a dialog saying
that it was added to the root.
- There could be more than one active bug, and this search could theoretically
be slow, but the refresh will alsways be dominated by the server job anyway.

Bug.WithStack:
If a task is actived in a query category and you close eclipse, you will not be able to refresh any of the bugzilla stuff since bugs should not be active.
A work around is to either deactivate the task, or make sure that there is a copy of that task in another category Consider if this is easier to fix by bringing up the old query results. That would solve this problem, and make the task list behave the way more like people expect it to. The <needs refresh> thing is still a good idea to leave on though, since it's a useful hint. Solve by: - On refresh, if a report is active but not in any category (e.g. query category or task category) then add it to the root, and pop up a dialog saying that it was added to the root. - There could be more than one active bug, and this search could theoretically be slow, but the refresh will alsways be dominated by the server job anyway.
This has been fixed by the above method. It notifies the user that it has been moved to the root.
Bug.WithOutStack:
If a task is actived in a query category and you close eclipse, you will not be able to refresh any of the bugzilla stuff since bugs should not be active.
A work around is to either deactivate the task, or make sure that there is a copy of that task in another category Consider if this is easier to fix by bringing up the old query results. That would solve this problem, and make the task list behave the way more like people expect it to. The <needs refresh> thing is still a good idea to leave on though, since it's a useful hint. Solve by: - On refresh, if a report is active but not in any category (e.g. query category or task category) then add it to the root, and pop up a dialog saying that it was added to the root. - There could be more than one active bug, and this search could theoretically be slow, but the refresh will alsways be dominated by the server job anyway.
This has been fixed by the above method. It notifies the user that it has been moved to the root.

Bug.Summery: WSDL editor does not show Apache Axis generate WSDL files correctly

Stacktrace.Reason: local part cannot be "null" when creating a QName

Bug.WithStack:
Driver: RC1
WSDL editor does not show Apache Axis generate WSDL files correctly. Basically, there's nothing shown in the WSDL editor (I just see the Imports/Types/Services/... boxes). Nothing in .log. The WSDL editor shows the WSDL wizard generated WSDL files correctly. Perhaps this is a rpc/encoded vs. a doc/lit thing? Here's the Apache Axis generated WSDL file:
<wsdl:definitions targetNamespace="http://test" xmlns:impl="http://test" xmlns:intf="http://test" xmlns:apachesoap="http://xml.apache.org/xml-soap" xmlns:wsdlsoap="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/wsdl/soap/" xmlns:soapenc="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/encoding/" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:wsdl="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/wsdl/" xmlns="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/wsdl/">
<wsdl:message name="heloRequest">
<wsdl:part name="s" type="xsd:string"/>
</wsdl:message>
<wsdl:message name="heloResponse">
<wsdl:part name="heloReturn" type="xsd:string"/>
</wsdl:message>
<wsdl:portType name="MyService">
<wsdl:operation name="helo" parameterOrder="s">
<wsdl:input name="heloRequest" message="impl:heloRequest"/>
<wsdl:output name="heloResponse" message="impl:heloResponse"/>
</wsdl:operation>
</wsdl:portType>
<wsdl:binding name="MyServiceSoapBinding" type="impl:MyService">
<wsdlsoap:binding style="rpc" transport="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/http"/>
<wsdl:operation name="helo">
<wsdlsoap:operation soapAction=""/>
<wsdl:input name="heloRequest">
<wsdlsoap:body use="encoded" encodingStyle="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/encoding/" namespace="http://test"/>
</wsdl:input>
<wsdl:output name="heloResponse">
<wsdlsoap:body use="encoded" encodingStyle="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/encoding/" namespace="http://test"/>
</wsdl:output>
</wsdl:operation>

Created attachment 24955 Not loading a WSDL without a Definiton name attribute.
simple patch to ensure we finish loading a WSDL file without a Definition name attribute. comitted patch, thanks Rich! Verified in 0722 Close bug. Created attachment 44590 Patch for the missing definition name
The previous patch makes it possible to open WSDL files missing the name definition without throwing an exception, however, the name element would be null instead of the empty string. This is solved in the attached patch.

Bug.Summery: XML file generated from XSD has null encoding, editor fails
Bug.WithStack:
Using the New wizard to generate an XML file from an XML Schema (either using a workspace schema file or a catalog entry) generates the .xml file with a header:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="null"?>
This prevents opening the file using either the XML editor or a text editor.
Workaround: open with Text editor and click Set Encoding... button to set a valid encoding. Then open with XML editor. Sorry, all, this was an unintened partial clean-up of some old code that did not take advantage of Eclipse's way of signifying charset. See But 102070.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 103767 *** Marking as verified just to signify correctly categorized.
closing (verified on wtp 1.5.1 9/23/06 build that this is no longer a problem)
Bug.WithOutStack:
Using the New wizard to generate an XML file from an XML Schema (either using a workspace schema file or a catalog entry) generates the .xml file with a header:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="null"?>
This prevents opening the file using either the XML editor or a text editor.
Workaround: open with Text editor and click Set Encoding... button to set a valid encoding. Then open with XML editor. Sorry, all, this was an unintened partial clean-up of some old code that did not take advantage of Eclipse's way of signifying charset. See But 102070.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 103767 *** Marking as verified just to signify correctly categorized.
closing (verified on wtp 1.5.1 9/23/06 build that this is no longer a problem)

Bug.Summery: [Wizards] Cannot import mulitple projects as Java projects
Bug.WithStack:
I posed this question to the newsgroup and it was suggested I entered an enhancement request for this:
I am having a problem checking out a CVS module alias, (ALL - which expands to around 50 modules). To be more specific, the created projects (one per module as expected) are not created a Java projects, ie empty <buildSpec> and <natures> are empty. I was unable to add a builder through Eclipse.
Manually editing the .project files and identifying the src folder in the build path in Eclipse did not actually identify the src folder, the icon did not change and the folder still expands one level at a time.
So starting from scratch and checking out one folder at a time, using the "Check out as a project configured using the New Project Wizard" (which is NOT an option when checking out an expanding module alias) all is well. This is related to bug 102527. However, it differs slightly in that multiple projects are involved. CVS currently does support single project configuration (as you have mentioned) because it can make use of support offered by the UI and JDT. However, no such support exists for multiple projects. Moving to JDT since they would need to provide some means of configuring multiple projects for this to work. Michael, you mention an existing single project configuration support? What is that exactly? Martin, I am refering to the New Project wizard which allows the user to pick the type of project. We hacked in support that would open the New Project wizard, catch the creation of the project using a delta listener and then checkout into that project. This works wiuth a single project but obviously doesn't scale well to multiple projects. I wonder if it would be possible for JDT to auto-detect that new simple projects are actually Java projects? We added the ability to CVS to auto-detected and shae CVS projects that are imported from the file system and added a preference to diable this in the rare cases where the user doesn't want this. Would this be possible for JDT to do? Another option would be to surface some sort of project-type analysis that can be surfaced as API to any import mechanism that they can run at the end of their import. Such a mechanism could even have a wizard page or dialog associated with it that would allow the user to see what types of associations are possible for he projects they have imported. Of course, such a dialog would also need to offer the ability to make the associations. That would indeed be a good thing to have. Can you or core.resources create an extension point that we can implement?
For the user it might be best if he could specify on check out what the project is: Something like 'Check out as... Java Projects'. I think that might be better than something automatic as a wrong guessed nature is again difficult to fix for the user. And, we're avoiding the problems of choosing if its a Java project or a WebProject.
I guess the importer can also first check is a .projects is a around and only ask the question when not found.
Back to Team. We'll investigate possible solutions and see what we can come up with. We do not have the manpower to address this in 3.3.
Bug.WithOutStack:
I posed this question to the newsgroup and it was suggested I entered an enhancement request for this:
I am having a problem checking out a CVS module alias, (ALL - which expands to around 50 modules). To be more specific, the created projects (one per module as expected) are not created a Java projects, ie empty <buildSpec> and <natures> are empty. I was unable to add a builder through Eclipse.

So starting from scratch and checking out one folder at a time, using the "Check out as a project configured using the New Project Wizard" (which is NOT an option when checking out an expanding module alias) all is well. This is related to bug 102527. However, it differs slightly in that multiple projects are involved. CVS currently does support single project configuration (as you have mentioned) because it can make use of support offered by the UI and JDT. However, no such support exists for multiple projects. Moving to JDT since they would need to provide some means of configuring multiple projects for this to work. Michael, you mention an existing single project configuration support? What is that exactly? Martin, I am refering to the New Project wizard which allows the user to pick the type of project. We hacked in support that would open the New Project wizard, catch the creation of the project using a delta listener and then checkout into that project. This works wiuth a single project but obviously doesn't scale well to multiple projects. I wonder if it would be possible for JDT to auto-detect that new simple projects are actually Java projects? Bug.Summery: Server Explorer virtual folder should only show when they apply
Bug.WithStack: Using the SE on a Derby connection exposes a Sequences and UDTs folders which do are not supported in Derby. The SE should not disaplay these folders. Applied fix on July 18th, 2005. Verified fixed.
Bug.WithOutStack: Using the SE on a Derby connection exposes a Sequences and UDTs folders which do are not supported in Derby. The SE should not disaplay these folders. Applied fix on July 18th, 2005. Verified fixed.

Bug.Summery: Derby view refresh fails
Bug.WithStack: Refreshing a Derby view duplicates all the columns in that view. Applied fix on July 18th, 2005. Verified fixed.
Bug.WithOutStack: Refreshing a Derby view duplicates all the columns in that view. Applied fix on July 18th, 2005. Verified fixed.

Bug.Summery: The SQL editor should use .sql as the default extension
Bug.WithStack: The SQL editor should use .sql as the default extension. This will allows the SQL Editor to be used the next time the user tries to open the script. Applied fix on July 18th, 2005. Verified fixed.
Bug.WithOutStack: The SQL editor should use .sql as the default extension. This will allows the SQL Editor to be used the next time the user tries to open the script. Applied fix on July 18th, 2005. Verified fixed.

Bug.Summery: If a user had just swt.jar in their project path let them know this is wrong
Bug.WithStack: User scenario: Add swt.jar to the build path and get compile working OK. Can't use VE. Solution: We should give them a nice user friendly error when the VE is opened telling them how to correctly configure the project
Bug.WithOutStack: User scenario: Add swt.jar to the build path and get compile working OK. Can't use VE. Solution: We should give them a nice user friendly error when the VE is opened telling them how to correctly configure the project

Bug.Summery: Browser 'forward' corrupts plaintext display
Bug.WithStack:
Follow a link from a locally-saved webpage to a plaintext file. Click 'back' Click 'forward' Plaintext is no longer rendered as monotype; it is rendered in a proportional font and all line-breaks are collapsed.
I can only reproduce this if the files are locally saved (i.e. on disk). I cannot reproduce it with hosted sites. I cannot reproduce this problem, using http://dev.eclipse.org/viewcvs/index.cgi/org.eclipse.swt.snippets/src/org/eclips e/swt/snippets/Snippet128.java?rev=HEAD&content-type=text/vnd.viewcvs-markup . Are you able to attach the html and txt files that show this happening?
Created attachment 25402 Eclipse Browser view Created attachment 25403 Browser from Snippet 128 Created attachment 25404 Ghostscript API Documentation (API.htm)
Should be placed in a /doc directory Links to iapi.h on first line of 'Exported Functions' Created attachment 25405 Ghostscript source file (iapi.h)
Should be placed in a /src directory I am able to reproduce the bug using the snippet as well as the Eclipse Browser View. I have attached a screenshot of both cases as well as API.html which links to iapi.h Having intalled the Internet Explorer 7 for Windows XP beta 1, I am not able to reproduce this bug any more. It seems that it was a problem with the underlying IE6 engine that Eclipse uses (although I have never been able to reproduce this bug in a standalone IE6 window). Revisited, I still cannot duplicate this with the provided files, on either win2000 or XP. The IE versions on them were 6.0.2800.1106 and 6.0.2800.1106.xpxp2.050301-1526, respectively.
Given this, and that you see it work with IE 7, I'm going to mark the report as WORKSFORME. If you have any more ideas for making this reproducable, especially if you somehow run into it with IE 7, then please reopen the report, thanks.

Should be placed in a /doc directory Links to iapi.h on first line of 'Exported Functions' Created attachment 25405 Ghostscript source file (iapi.h)
Should be placed in a /src directory I am able to reproduce the bug using the snippet as well as the Eclipse Browser View. I have attached a screenshot of both cases as well as API.html which links to iapi.h Having intalled the Internet Explorer 7 for Windows XP beta 1, I am not able to reproduce this bug any more. It seems that it was a problem with the underlying IE6 engine that Eclipse uses (although I have never been able to reproduce this bug in a standalone IE6 window). Revisited, I still cannot duplicate this with the provided files, on either win2000 or XP. The IE versions on them were 6.0.2800.1106 and 6.0.2800.1106.xpxp2.050301-1526, respectively.
Given this, and that you see it work with IE 7, I'm going to mark the report as WORKSFORME. If you have any more ideas for making this reproducable, especially if you somehow run into it with IE 7, then please reopen the report, thanks.

Bug.Summery: Selection Search from CView doesn't work
Bug.WithStack:
In FindAction, we call getFullyQualifiedName(ICElement)when the user selects something from the CView. This appends '::' as it climbs up the CModel. So, if we selected MyClass in the CView, we would actually search for ::MyClass. This always leads to no results. Note that search from the Editor and Outline view work well.
Can you take a look at this? Thanks! Created attachment 24903 fix for this PR Take a look at the attached patch. Patch applied!
Bug.WithOutStack:
In FindAction, we call getFullyQualifiedName(ICElement)when the user selects something from the CView. This appends '::' as it climbs up the CModel. So, if we selected MyClass in the CView, we would actually search for ::MyClass. This always leads to no results. Note that search from the Editor and Outline view work well.
Can you take a look at this? Thanks! Created attachment 24903 fix for this PR Take a look at the attached patch. Patch applied!

Bug.Summery: (PatchAttached)Add option to wrap comments in CVS history view
Bug.WithStack:
CVS history view is using a horisontal scroller without word wrap. There should be an option to enable wrapping. Created attachment 24881 Patch implementing this functionality
Added an action to view menu for CVS resource history to flip word wrap on and off. Setting is saved similar to other actions from this menu. Bug.Summery: Manifest files and plugin packaging

Lines.Line: 1.Open the manifest.mf file then delete the Bundle-Classpath header.
2. Change the build.properties:
Change all occurences of the old jar name to simply a dot. (.)
There should be one on the bin.includes line. For instance, if your
bin.includes line used to have core.jar, that will be replaced with a ..For
instance: bin.includes=about.html,.,META-INF/MANIFEST.MF
Change source.foo.jar= to source..= (that is source dot dot)
Change output.foo.jar= to output..= (that is output dot dot)
There may be others like jars.compile.order, etc
3.Change the feature :
find all features that list your plug-in and add following to the related
<plugin> tag:
unpack="false"
- create the Manifest file
Open the plugin.xml file then select on the Overview page the 'create an OSGI
bundel manifest' option. This will automatically create the manifest file and
update the build.properties
- set the plugin to be packaged in one jar. To do that:
1.Open the manifest.mf file then delete the Bundle-Classpath header.
2. Change the build.properties:
Change all occurences of the old jar name to simply a dot. (.)
There should be one on the bin.includes line. For instance, if your
bin.includes line used to have core.jar, that will be replaced with a ..For
instance: bin.includes=about.html,.,META-INF/MANIFEST.MF
Change source.foo.jar= to source..= (that is source dot dot)
Change output.foo.jar= to output..= (that is output dot dot)
There may be others like jars.compile.order, etc

Bug.WithStack:
As of Eclipse v3.1, the recommended way to package plugins is as OSGi bundles (manifest files) and using jar files. Although they are fairly easy to do, combined these changes will improve unzip/install time, reduce disk footprint by 30% or more, reduce startup time, and improve runtime management of the plugins.
Steps for creating the manifest file and for defining the plugin packaging in one jar( for a concrete sample look at the o.e.h.ui plugin): - create the Manifest file Open the plugin.xml file then select on the Overview page the 'create an OSGI bundel manifest' option. This will automatically create the manifest file and update the build.properties - set the plugin to be packaged in one jar. To do that: 1.Open the manifest.mf file then delete the Bundle-Classpath header. 2. Change the build.properties: Change all occurences of the old jar name to simply a dot. (.) There should be one on the bin.includes line. For instance, if your bin.includes line used to have core.jar, that will be replaced with a ..For instance: bin.includes=about.html,.,META-INF/MANIFEST.MF Change source.foo.jar= to source..= (that is source dot dot) Change output.foo.jar= to output..= (that is output dot dot) There may be others like jars.compile.order, etc
3.Change the feature : find all features that list your plug-in and add following to the related <plugin> tag: unpack="false"
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 90736 *** Reopen the bug so that this bugzilla can be used to check in the actual work. org.eclipse.hyades.resources.database has been changed to a JAR, but org.eclipse.tptp.platform.models was not because o.e.t.p.m is packaged in the RAC. I'll open a separate defect for o.e.t.p.m and mark this one "FIXED" because it shows that work was done in 4.1 i1 for this. Reopening because I found out that this plug-in is used by the stand-alone LTA. I backed out the change for this defect, and this plug-in should be migrated to a JAR in 4.2 (or the next API-breaking release). Changing to 4.2 because this change should not happen in 4.1. Moving to future because 4.2 is not an API-breaking release. Can you add the Manifest file in 4.2 This is not a breaking change Are you sure that adding a Manifest isn't a breaking change? I thought that adding it meant that the API in the plugin class needed to change, i.e., from this: public DatabasePlugin(IPluginDescriptor descriptor) { to this: public DatabasePlugin() { I thought that the IPluginDescriptor wouldn't work in a plug-in after the "org.eclipse.core.runtime.compatibility" plug-in wasn't used any more, and that once you created a Manifest that you had to remove "org.eclipse.core.runtime.compatibility" from the dependencies list? Yes, you will need to remove the compatibility layer but plugin class is not API so there is nothing to be broken
Pleaes review this with Marius; I don't agree that creating the manifest file and removing the compatibility layer is a breaking change
This change can be done in 4.2 Hi Valentina,
Consulting Marius alone wouldn't be enough because this involves the packaging inside the RAC, and the RAC is extended by some consumers. I thought that the path & structure of the RAC zip was public API because changes to it would require RAC extenders to update their pluginconfig.xml file, and I'm not familiar enough with the RAC to know if the changes would stop there.
Here's an example response that we received when we changed the RAC path: http://dev.eclipse.org/mhonarc/lists/tptp-tracing-profiling-tools-dev/msg00081.html
What do you think?
Thanks, Ruth. I think we are talking about different things; you are referring to jar packaging while I was asking if the plugin can have the manifest file created and use the osgi bundle instead of the compatibility layer. There are no plugin packaging or API changes involved in doing that.
I talked to Marius last week and he understood my point and was planning to fix the problem. I already did part of it, I will close it today. I will not convert the plugins to JAR (because we cannot do that in the two plugins that are model related) but I will do the other changes. Fix in CVS. *** Bug 107063 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** As of TPTP 4.6.0, TPTP is in maintenance mode and focusing on improving quality by resolving relevant enhancements/defects and increasing test coverage through test creation, automation, Build Verification Tests (BVTs), and expanded run-time execution. As part of the TPTP Bugzilla housecleaning process (see http://wiki.eclipse.org/Bugzilla_Housecleaning_Processes), this enhancement/defect is verified/closed by the Project Lead since this enhancement/defect has been resolved and unverified for more than 1 year and considered to be fixed. If this enhancement/defect is still unresolved and reproducible in the latest TPTP release (http://www.eclipse.org/tptp/home/downloads/), please re-open.

Bug.Summery: Create Manifest file for GLA plugins

Lines.Line: 1.Open the manifest.mf file then delete the Bundle-Classpath header.
2. Change the build.properties:
Change all occurences of the old jar name to simply a dot. (.)
There should be one on the bin.includes line. For instance, if your
bin.includes line used to have core.jar, that will be replaced with a ..For
instance: bin.includes=about.html,.,META-INF/MANIFEST.MF
Change source.foo.jar= to source..= (that is source dot dot)
Change output.foo.jar= to output..= (that is output dot dot)
There may be others like jars.compile.order, etc
3.Change the feature :
find all features that list your plug-in and add following to the related
<plugin> tag:
unpack="false"
Please carefully review the result of packaging a plugin in a jar ( second
step in the defect description). There are some scenarios where this will
break components which depend on the jar name generated by the plugin.
As an example, any plugins generating jars packaged with the RAC runtime
should not be packaged as a plugin since this can break RAC.
- create the Manifest file
Open the plugin.xml file then select on the Overview page the 'create an OSGI
bundel manifest' option. This will automatically create the manifest file and
update the build.properties
- set the plugin to be packaged in one jar. To do that:
1.Open the manifest.mf file then delete the Bundle-Classpath header.
2. Change the build.properties:
Change all occurences of the old jar name to simply a dot. (.)
There should be one on the bin.includes line. For instance, if your
bin.includes line used to have core.jar, that will be replaced with a ..For
instance: bin.includes=about.html,.,META-INF/MANIFEST.MF
Change source.foo.jar= to source..= (that is source dot dot)
Change output.foo.jar= to output..= (that is output dot dot)
There may be others like jars.compile.order, etc

Bug.WithStack:
As of Eclipse v3.1, the recommended way to package plugins is as OSGi bundles (manifest files) and using jar files. Although they are fairly easy to do, combined these changes will improve unzip/install time, reduce disk footprint by 30% or more, reduce startup time, and improve runtime management of the plugins.
Steps for creating the manifest file and for defining the plugin packaging in one jar( for a concrete sample look at the o.e.h.ui plugin): - create the Manifest file Open the plugin.xml file then select on the Overview page the 'create an OSGI bundel manifest' option. This will automatically create the manifest file and update the build.properties - set the plugin to be packaged in one jar. To do that: 1.Open the manifest.mf file then delete the Bundle-Classpath header. 2. Change the build.properties: Change all occurences of the old jar name to simply a dot. (.) There should be one on the bin.includes line. For instance, if your bin.includes line used to have core.jar, that will be replaced with a ..For instance: bin.includes=about.html,.,META-INF/MANIFEST.MF Change source.foo.jar= to source..= (that is source dot dot) Change output.foo.jar= to output..= (that is output dot dot) There may be others like jars.compile.order, etc
3.Change the feature : find all features that list your plug-in and add following to the related <plugin> tag: unpack="false" Please carefully review the result of packaging a plugin in a jar ( second step in the defect description). There are some scenarios where this will break components which depend on the jar name generated by the plugin. As an example, any plugins generating jars packaged with the RAC runtime should not be packaged as a plugin since this can break RAC.
Note that the creation of the manifest file does not affect these 'runtime' plugins ( first step in this defect description ); the manifest file can be safely created for any type of plugin. This will reduce the eclipse startup time since the manifest file is created on the fly when the plugin is first loaded
The plugins covered in this defect are:
org.eclipse.hyades.logging.adapter org.eclipse.hyades.logging.parsers
These plugins are packaged in the RAC and also their runtime jars and other files are packaged in a standalone GLA packaging. Therefore, for these plugins, the change to create the manifest file will be made at this time but the packaging as a single jar will not be made at this time as it would require extensive changes to the GLA run-time to support this packaging. Committed plugin changes to TPTP Head CVS (plugin.xml, build.properties, MANIFEST.MF). As of TPTP 4.6.0, TPTP is in maintenance mode and focusing on improving quality by resolving relevant enhancements/defects and increasing test coverage through test creation, automation, Build Verification Tests (BVTs), and expanded run-time execution. As part of the TPTP Bugzilla housecleaning process (see http://wiki.eclipse.org/Bugzilla_Housecleaning_Processes), this enhancement/defect is verified/closed by the Project Lead since this enhancement/defect has been resolved and unverified for more than 1 year and considered to be fixed. If this enhancement/defect is still unresolved and reproducible in the latest TPTP release (http://www.eclipse.org/tptp/home/downloads/), please re-open.

break components which depend on the jar name generated by the plugin.
As an example, any plugins generating jars packaged with the RAC runtime
should not be packaged as a plugin since this can break RAC.
- create the Manifest file
Open the plugin.xml file then select on the Overview page the 'create an OSGI
bundel manifest' option. This will automatically create the manifest file and
update the build.properties
- set the plugin to be packaged in one jar. To do that:
1.Open the manifest.mf file then delete the Bundle-Classpath header.
2. Change the build.properties:
Change all occurences of the old jar name to simply a dot. (.)
There should be one on the bin.includes line. For instance, if your
bin.includes line used to have core.jar, that will be replaced with a ..For
instance: bin.includes=about.html,.,META-INF/MANIFEST.MF
Change source.foo.jar= to source..= (that is source dot dot)
Change output.foo.jar= to output..= (that is output dot dot)
There may be others like jars.compile.order, etc

Bug.WithStack:
As of Eclipse v3.1, the recommended way to package plugins is as OSGi bundles (manifest files) and using jar files. Although they are fairly easy to do, combined these changes will improve unzip/install time, reduce disk footprint by 30% or more, reduce startup time, and improve runtime management of the plugins.
Steps for creating the manifest file and for defining the plugin packaging in one jar( for a concrete sample look at the o.e.h.ui plugin): - create the Manifest file Open the plugin.xml file then select on the Overview page the 'create an OSGI bundel manifest' option. This will automatically create the manifest file and update the build.properties - set the plugin to be packaged in one jar. To do that: 1.Open the manifest.mf file then delete the Bundle-Classpath header. 2. Change the build.properties: Change all occurences of the old jar name to simply a dot. (.) There should be one on the bin.includes line. For instance, if your bin.includes line used to have core.jar, that will be replaced with a ..For instance: bin.includes=about.html,.,META-INF/MANIFEST.MF Change source.foo.jar= to source..= (that is source dot dot) Change output.foo.jar= to output..= (that is output dot dot) There may be others like jars.compile.order, etc
3.Change the feature : find all features that list your plug-in and add following to the related <plugin> tag: unpack="false" Please carefully review the result of packaging a plugin in a jar ( second step in the defect description). There are some scenarios where this will break components which depend on the jar name generated by the plugin. As an example, any plugins generating jars packaged with the RAC runtime should not be packaged as a plugin since this can break RAC.
Note that the creation of the manifest file does not affect these 'runtime' plugins ( first step in this defect description ); the manifest file can be safely created for any type of plugin. This will reduce the eclipse startup time since the manifest file is created on the fly when the plugin is first loaded
As per the August 5, 2005 Architecture Group call, the following plug-ins will NOT be packaged as OSGi bundles/JAR file with a manifest file:
org.apache.jakarta_commons_logging org.eclipse.hyades.logging.core org.eclipse.hyades.test.tools.core
However, the following plug-ins will be packaged as OSGi bundles/JAR file with a manifest file:
org.apache.jakarta_log4j_logging org.eclipse.hyades.execution.correlation org.eclipse.hyades.execution.trace

Change output.foo.jar= to output..= (that is output dot dot)
There may be others like jars.compile.order, etc
3.Change the feature :
find all features that list your plug-in and add following to the related
<plugin> tag:
unpack="false"
Please carefully review the result of packaging a plugin in a jar ( second
step in the defect description). There are some scenarios where this will
break components which depend on the jar name generated by the plugin.
As an example, any plugins generating jars packaged with the RAC runtime
should not be packaged as a plugin since this can break RAC.
- create the Manifest file
Open the plugin.xml file then select on the Overview page the 'create an OSGI
bundel manifest' option. This will automatically create the manifest file and
update the build.properties
- set the plugin to be packaged in one jar. To do that:
1.Open the manifest.mf file then delete the Bundle-Classpath header.
2. Change the build.properties:
Change all occurences of the old jar name to simply a dot. (.)
There should be one on the bin.includes line. For instance, if your
bin.includes line used to have core.jar, that will be replaced with a ..For
instance: bin.includes=about.html,.,META-INF/MANIFEST.MF
Change source.foo.jar= to source..= (that is source dot dot)
Change output.foo.jar= to output..= (that is output dot dot)
There may be others like jars.compile.order, etc

Bug.WithStack:
As of Eclipse v3.1, the recommended way to package plugins is as OSGi bundles (manifest files) and using jar files. Although they are fairly easy to do, combined these changes will improve unzip/install time, reduce disk footprint by 30% or more, reduce startup time, and improve runtime management of the plugins.
Steps for creating the manifest file and for defining the plugin packaging in one jar( for a concrete sample look at the o.e.h.ui plugin): - create the Manifest file Open the plugin.xml file then select on the Overview page the 'create an OSGI bundel manifest' option. This will automatically create the manifest file and update the build.properties - set the plugin to be packaged in one jar. To do that: 1.Open the manifest.mf file then delete the Bundle-Classpath header. 2. Change the build.properties: Change all occurences of the old jar name to simply a dot. (.) There should be one on the bin.includes line. For instance, if your bin.includes line used to have core.jar, that will be replaced with a ..For instance: bin.includes=about.html,.,META-INF/MANIFEST.MF Change source.foo.jar= to source..= (that is source dot dot) Change output.foo.jar= to output..= (that is output dot dot) There may be others like jars.compile.order, etc
3.Change the feature : find all features that list your plug-in and add following to the related <plugin> tag: unpack="false" Please carefully review the result of packaging a plugin in a jar ( second step in the defect description). There are some scenarios where this will break components which depend on the jar name generated by the plugin. As an example, any plugins generating jars packaged with the RAC runtime should not be packaged as a plugin since this can break RAC.
Note that the creation of the manifest file does not affect these 'runtime' plugins ( first step in this defect description ); the manifest file can be safely created for any type of plugin. This will reduce the eclipse startup time since the manifest file is created on the fly when the plugin is first loaded
Done, please note that the Bundle-Classpath header is still there, and that the plugins needs to be unpacked (feature). When the complete procedure is followed, there are issues at run time with inner classes.
To sum up: Manifest are created and the build.properties refers to the jar name, not to '.'
As of TPTP 4.6.0, TPTP is in maintenance mode and focusing on improving quality by resolving relevant enhancements/defects and increasing test coverage through test creation, automation, Build Verification Tests (BVTs), and expanded run-time execution. As part of the TPTP Bugzilla housecleaning process (see http://wiki.eclipse.org/Bugzilla_Housecleaning_Processes), this enhancement/defect is verified/closed by the Project Lead since this enhancement/defect has been resolved and unverified for more than 1 year and considered to be fixed. If this enhancement/defect is still unresolved and reproducible in the latest TPTP release (http://www.eclipse.org/tptp/home/downloads/), please re-open.

Bug.Summery: serlet wiz leaves HelloWorld.java empty
Bug.WithStack:
Following the Testing the Creation of Annotated and Non-Annotated Servlets in the Web Tools Project Tutorial i got an empty HelloWorld.java. None of the selectet method stubs have been created. Works on RC1 driver. Please provide more detailed steps to reproduce if still fails. Is annotations used, is annotations and xdoc configured properly if so? This is part of a mass update to close out all stale WTP resolved bugs from the 1.0.x and 1.5.0 timeframe. If you feel this bug was closed inappropriately, please reopen.
Thanks, John Lanuti

Bug.Summery: Use the wrong start or stop script in two server instances situation

Lines.Line: 1. Start the first server. (startWebLogicMib.cmd)
2. Start the second one. (startWebLogicWeb.cmd)
3. Stop the first server. (stopWebLogicMib.cmd)

Bug.WithStack:
Summary: For some reasons, I've to start two application servers based on Weblogic v8.1. These two servers use the same config.xml file and located on the same directory but use different start or stop scripts like startWebLogicMib.cmd, stopWebLogicMib.cmd, startWebLogicWeb.cmd and stopWebLogicWeb.cmd.
Problem: After I start these two servers, it will always use the scripts belong to the last started server.
Setps: 1. Start the first server. (startWebLogicMib.cmd) 2. Start the second one. (startWebLogicWeb.cmd) 3. Stop the first server. (stopWebLogicMib.cmd)
Result: It will execute the stopWebLogicWeb.cmd script.
Work around: I can execute stopWebLogicMib.cmd to stop the server by myself. This looks identical to the bug (#103705) in which property values are being shared between generic server instances of the same type; I'm not the owner so I can't resolve as duplicate but I think that's what should be done here.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 103705 *** Closing old bugs that haven't had any activity in a long time.

Bug.Summery: xml editor exception for non-ant files with a root project element
Bug.WithStack:
tested on wtp m7 rc1
Trying to open an xml file with a xsd declaration and a root <project> element + a <target> element results in a blank editor with the message: "the document is empty. Right mouse click here to insert content" (right click does nothing)
This is a sample document:
===== <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <project xmlns="http://maven.apache.org/POM/4.0.0" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://maven.apache.org/POM/4.0.0 http://maven.apache.org/maven-v4_0_0.xsd"> <build> <plugins> <plugin> <configuration> <target>1.3</target> </configuration> </plugin> </plugins> </build> </project> =====
It seems that, despite of the xsd declaration, eclipse is using the ant editor for this file. This is the error log:
!ENTRY org.eclipse.wst.sse.ui 2 2 2005-07-16 12:36:53.593 !MESSAGE StructuredTextEditor being used without StructuredDocument
!ENTRY org.eclipse.wst.sse.ui 2 2 2005-07-16 12:36:53.593 !MESSAGE Input Name: pom.xml
!ENTRY org.eclipse.wst.sse.ui 2 2 2005-07-16 12:36:53.603 !MESSAGE Unexpected IDocument implementation: org.eclipse.ant.internal.ui.editor.text.PartiallySynchronizedDocument
renaming the root <project> to something different (e.g. <projectx>) and closing/reopening the file makes the editor work. It also works after removing the contained <target> element. A big issue for people using maven (the sample document is a maven 2 pom) We'll look if can work around for 0.7.
Fabrizio, can you tell me ... do all "maven" files have the schema defined in them?
If so, we might be able to work around bug 89195 by defining a "maven content type" but will have to investigate which would "win" if both claim validity for this file. And, I assume the file names are always completely open, generic.xml files, right? (not like "build.xml" is pretty typically "reserved" for ant?)
> do all "maven" files have the schema defined in them? No, the xds is optional (and usually most of the maven project files don't contain the schema reference)
> And, I assume the file names are always completely open, generic.xml files, right? (not like "build.xml" is pretty typically "reserved" for ant?) No, actually the names are "project.xml" and "maven.xml" for maven 1 and "pom.xml" for maven 2 (ant the name can't be changed like you can do for ant files)
I tried the suggested workaround: adding a specific pom.xml entry in "content type"->"xml" (note, without any special "maven" content type) makes the editor work correctly. After removing the "pom.xml" entry, leaving only the default *.xml mapping, the editor fails to load.
Well, I think the best work-around for now -- WTP 0.7 -- is to simply explicitly list that "project.xml" and "maven.xml" and "pom.xml" are "XML Content Type". There might be some future improvement from bug 89195 ... but ... not sure how much can be done -- the overall "element signature" of these two types seems pretty similar (project, target etc .... I'm not sure there's an easy way to distinguish 'ant' and 'maven' based on tags. And ... since the maven file names can not be changed, sounds like a good candidate for a "hard coded" list of files.
The only question if is is "fair" to let each user do this, or "safe" for us to do it in our distributed plugins. Some reasons it might be not "safe" ... do other "types of content" assume file names like "project.xml" means something (besides maven, or do ant users ever use that for their ant files?).
As I write this, seems not very safe for us to add to the potential for "usurped content types" ... so, I think best we can do is leave it to users to use the contentType preference settings, add these three file names explicitly to "XML Content Type" . That gives them higher priority to be resovled as "XML Content Type" instead of "Ant Content Type". Feel free to offer other opinons and/or suggestions.
Even though a hassel, I'm not sure we know any way to fix this safely (wihout adding to the potential for conflicts) other than to let users define themselves in their own preferences. Therefore, while opened as 'major', I'm setting to "P4" to indicate no fix is planned for WTP .7. The "workaround" is pretty easy to do.
Long term, the ant content type could be improved to ensure the "peeked at" element signature really matched the ant content model (for example <target>1.4</target> does not seem like a valid ant statement (from what I know of it), but the ant content type assumes it is.
Oh, and I should note here, as I have for Ant, we may eventually want to define some re-usable "content type describers" that take adavantage of a processing instruction in xml files to unamiguously identify the content type ... such as <?eclipse-maven?> that users could potentially take advantage of to unambiguously mark something as a certain type of content. Just an idea.
Moving back to appropriate priority now that 0.7 is released. It's not that easy for the user to set. I tried without success.
I have associated pom.xml to the XML content type, but then, it is still the ANT editor that is used. And of curse, a problem is reported with the first line <project xmlns="http://maven.apache.org/maven-v4_0_0.xsd">
If I go in file association, and I add pom.xml (and put XML Editor as the default), when I open the file, I still get
!ENTRY org.eclipse.wst.sse.ui 2 2 2005-07-16 12:36:53.593 !MESSAGE StructuredTextEditor being used without StructuredDocument
!ENTRY org.eclipse.wst.sse.ui 2 2 2005-07-16 12:36:53.593 !MESSAGE Input Name: pom.xml
!ENTRY org.eclipse.wst.sse.ui 2 2 2005-07-16 12:36:53.603 !MESSAGE Unexpected IDocument implementation: org.eclipse.ant.internal.ui.editor.text.PartiallySynchronizedDocument
So either, the workaround doesn't work, either I miss something when setting the preferences. And the second case, it means that something is not intuitive enought This remains a year later a very annoying bug, and the workaround doesn't work - although the content styling changes is "maven.xml" is assigned to be of XML type, WST still applies validation rules for Ant, and for example complains on the following maven file:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <project default="full" > <goal name="full"> <attainGoal name="jar:install" /> </goal> </project>
"Default target full does not exist in this project".
That "target" message doesn't some from WST ... it comes from ant component. And, I believe, only when opened with the ant editor. And, to make it worse, I think once the ant editor creates the marker, its never gets removed, which I mention just because I wonder if there error message of yours has just been "hanging around" for a long time? Or ... does it just appear at some point.
Is there any way to get rid of marker at all? This is VERY annoying.
(In reply to comment #9) > That "target" message doesn't some from WST ... it comes from ant component. > And, I believe, only when opened with the ant editor. And, to make it worse, I > think once the ant editor creates the marker, its never gets removed, which I > mention just because I wonder if there error message of yours has just been > "hanging around" for a long time? Or ... does it just appear at some point. > The behavior doesn't play well with maven, which uses the "project" root tag. The original problem described in comment #0 seems to be fixed. I can double-click an XML file with those contents and it opens up the WST XML editor just fine. I do get hit with what's described in comment #8 though since Eclipse opens that file up with the Ant editor.
I am not sure what a correct solution would be. How would the Ant plug-in know that that file is not actually an Ant build file?
It does look like you can work around this by using 'Open With' to use the XML editor (and then forever and after Eclipse should use that editor when you double-click), though. (In reply to comment #8) > "Default target full does not exist in this project".
WST doesn't do anything with Ant, it's Ant telling you that particular message.
(In reply to comment #13) > (In reply to comment #8) > > "Default target full does not exist in this project". > > WST doesn't do anything with Ant, it's Ant telling you that particular message. >
What Nitin says is correct. If you open this with the WTP XML editor there is no validation error message reported. If you open it with the Eclipse ANT editor then you get the error message for comment #8. Nitin can this one be closed now?
Verified in WTP 3.2 that file with project does not give any error when opened with WTP XML editor. Can be closed From reviewing the comments it sounds like the original problem has been fixed and the other issue from comment 8 isn't a WTP issue. Resolving. If this is still an issue, please reopen the bug. Thanks.

Bug.Summery: Give the developer a better control over the compilation process (through 'build file', folder, etc.)
Bug.WithStack:
Working on a project with a couple of thousand classes, it's often usefull to disable the auto-build to be able to save changes but not yet activate them. Eclipse currently has an all or nothing situation which is very inconvenient at certain time. It would therefore be very easy to have a build class/folder/package (sub)menu. Please explain "very inconvenient at certain time" In my case, especially when working on refactorings. I like to be able to just recompile a package of a class instead of the whole project. The idea is to be able to type and modify code, save the files, maybe see some possible warnings but not yet overwrite the old ones. This is not a functionality I need on a day-to-day basis, to do my work but it would come in handy now and them.
The compile action in the popupmenu when called from the Java-view would only be visible when build automatic is turned of. The Java builder is only a participant in the general builder framework. What you request would require to change the overall build manager. Moving to platform.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 33799 ***

Bug.Summery: Renaming a class causes a build failure
Bug.WithStack: After a performed the rename of a class from - 'className' to 'ClassName' - (through the refactoring submenu), my project build halted because Eclipse complained there already was a class with the same name. *** Bug 107467 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** Tried this in 3.2RC7 and it worked fine.
Bug.WithOutStack: After a performed the rename of a class from - 'className' to 'ClassName' - (through the refactoring submenu), my project build halted because Eclipse complained there already was a class with the same name. *** Bug 107467 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** Tried this in 3.2RC7 and it worked fine.

Bug.Summery: Taking Display Text in ComboBox from Import Values
Bug.WithStack: It could be usefull put automatically values to Display Text propertie during importing values to fields like ComboBox. It could be done by using another column in Import Values properties. When we want to use e.g. ids of customers in Data Sets query but display to users names of customers we would use two different columns in ComboBox: in Display Text - Customer Name, in Value - Cutomer Id. Users will see name, we will use id as a value of parameter. another enhancement request to be considered togehter with the cascading parameter enhancement. allow an additional column/field for each parameter as the displaying text while the existing col as the/value field. please evaluate if it can be done in 2.1. another enhancement request to be considered togehter with the cascading parameter enhancement. allow an additional column/field for each parameter as the displaying text while the existing col as the/value field. please evaluate if it can be done in 2.1. Cascading parameters, dynamic parameters already support a 'display Field' and 'Value Field' This enhancement is added in BIRT 2.0.
Bug.WithOutStack: It could be usefull put automatically values to Display Text propertie during importing values to fields like ComboBox. It could be done by using another column in Import Values properties. When we want to use e.g. ids of customers in Data Sets query but display to users names of customers we would use two different columns in ComboBox: in Display Text - Customer Name, in Value - Cutomer Id. Users will see name, we will use id as a value of parameter. another enhancement request to be considered togehter with the cascading parameter enhancement. allow an additional column/field for each parameter as the displaying text while the existing col as the/value field. please evaluate if it can be done in 2.1. another enhancement request to be considered togehter with the cascading parameter enhancement. allow an additional column/field for each parameter as the displaying text while the existing col as the/value field. please evaluate if it can be done in 2.1. Cascading parameters, dynamic parameters already support a 'display Field' and 'Value Field' This enhancement is added in BIRT 2.0.

Bug.Summery: [api] AbstractStructuredModel's setDocument() should be connectDocument()
Bug.WithStack:
Bug 103896 reveals a memory leak since some models add themselves as a listener to the document during setDocument.
Either we need to remove need for that listener stuff or change to 'connect' pattern so more obvious is needs to be disconnected.
For .7, we will minimize changes and just call 'setDocument(null)' when model is released, but that's not a good API contract to try and document. Not sure what to do with this one. In which class is this setDocument method, I don't see it in IStructuredModel. My guess this is something that is no longer an issue but some further input would be appreciated. No plan to change.
Bug.WithOutStack:
Bug 103896 reveals a memory leak since some models add themselves as a listener to the document during setDocument.
Either we need to remove need for that listener stuff or change to 'connect' pattern so more obvious is needs to be disconnected.
For .7, we will minimize changes and just call 'setDocument(null)' when model is released, but that's not a good API contract to try and document. Not sure what to do with this one. In which class is this setDocument method, I don't see it in IStructuredModel. My guess this is something that is no longer an issue but some further input would be appreciated. No plan to change.

Bug.Summery: Update RCP Tutorial part 1 for 3.1

Stacktrace.Reason: Application "org.eclipse.ui.tutorials.rcp.part1.application" could not be found in the registry. The applications available are: <NONE>.
Application "org.eclipse.ui.tutorials.rcp.part1.application" could not be found in the registry. The applications available are: <NONE>.
No application id has been found.

source_code.code: public void start(BundleContext context) throws Exception {
public void stop(BundleContext context) throws Exception {

Lines.Line: 1. it would be better to focus on 3.1 and not dwell on the past, ie. what
things were like pre-3.1.
Sentences like the ones below are an unnecessary distraction from the nice
workflow you are describing.
"This (OSGi bundle format) is different from previous versions where it was
recommended not to select this format."
and
"Trying out RCP applications used to be somewhat tedious. You had to create a
custom launch configuration, enter the right application name, and tweak the
plug-ins that were included."
2. "Unfortunately the Hello RCP template does not so we'll have to make one."
This was actually done intentionally, specifically for a case like yours (or
the upcoming RCP book) when someone is trying to demonstrate the creation of a
product from first principles. We have richer templates for those who want
them.
3. "You may see an error appear in the Problems view until you Synchronize
(see below). This is normal. "
This problem fell through the cracks in 3.1. Please tell people to first set
the product name on the overview page and then press New... This way, they
won't get the transient error marker and you wouldn't need to mention it.
We will fix this for 3.1.1 (i.e. if the product name is not set in the editor,
we will add an extra field to the wizard) as this seems to be an unpleasant
first impression to some.
4. "Typically this would not occur unless you are converting an older plug-in
that did not use MANIFEST.MF into one that does"
This is not correct. When you create a manifest.mf file for an existing plug-
in, PDE trims down the plugin.xml file to remove all redundant information,
and only extensions/extension points are left in the xml file.
5. Very flattered that the troubleshooting section has become obsolete :-)
Nice piece of work overall.
Regarding comment #3, the parts are being written sequentially as I get time so
I don't have a table of contents for the other two parts yet.
Regarding comment #4, 1) I wanted some backward looking stuff to help someone
who read the previous version tell what was different. Maybe I overdid it. 2) It
would be better if the templates were more configurable so I could mix and match
what went into it, like a checkbox for a feature, a product, a view, branding,
etc.. 3) ok, 4) I was referring to a manual conversion, I'll make that clearer.
Thanks for the comments.

Based on some feedback I've gotten on this article, I'm thinking of retooling it to get rid of the feature and making the example product plug-in based. The main reason is that it seems that hardly anybody uses just the plugins in the base rcp feature, and this has caused more than one person to stumble despite a note about that in the article. Anybody have any objections to this simplification?
